chapter.title: Introdaction
chapter.para: The Service Locator is a service that provides its consumers with a mechanism to discover service endpoints at run time. The Service Locator consists of two parts: An Endpoint repository and a CXF feature used to configure the use of the Service Locator at provider and consumer side. Like any standard CXF feature, the ServiceLocator Feature is configured separately for the service provider side and service consumer side. The provider side Locator Feature extension registers and deregisters service endpoints in the endpoint repository when the provider becomes available or unavailable. The consumer side Locator Feature extension transparently retrieves service endpoint addresses from the endpoint repository when a service call to a provider is to be made.
The configuration manual describes in detail the Service Locator Feature spring configuration.

chapter.title: Provider side configuration

section.title: Spring configuration
section.para:
To add the Locator feature to a CXF service provider, use <jaxws:features> including the bean org.talend.esb.locator.LocatorFeature. You should specify following properties in your Spring configuration file:
Property name
Description
endpointPrefix
necessary when running in a container where the endpoint is only relative to the conatiner. By default prefix is an empty string.
locatorEndpoints
Service Locator endpoints must be configurable in the feature. If not, the default localhost endpoint "localhost:2181" is taken as long as nobody sets new endpoints via setLocatorEndpoints. Specify the endpoints of all the instances belonging to the service locator ensemble the service locator client might be talking to. The service locator client will one by one pick an endpoint (the order is non-deterministic) to connect to the service locator until a connection is established.
connectionTimeout
specify the time the service locator client waits for a connection to get established. Must be greater than zero, by default 5000 ms.
sessionTimeout
specify the time out of the session established at the server. The session is kept alive by requests sent by the client. If the session is idle for a period of time that would timeout the session, the client will send a ping request to keep the session alive. Must be greater than zero and less than 60000, by default 5000 ms.

example.title: Talend ESB ServiceLocator Feature configuration for endpoint
example.programlisting:
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:jaxws="http://cxf.apache.org/jaxws" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.5.xsd http://cxf.apache.org/jaxws http://cxf.apache.org/schemas/jaxws.xsd">
<import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf.xml" /> <import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf-extension-soap.xml" /> <import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf-servlet.xml" />
<jaxws:endpoint xmlns:tns="http://talend.org/esb/examples/" id="greeter" implementor="demo.service.GreeterImpl" serviceName="tns:GreeterService" address="/GreeterService"> <jaxws:features> <bean class="org.talend.esb.locator.LocatorFeature"> <property name="endpointPrefix" value="http://localhost:8080/locator-demo-war"/> </bean> </jaxws:features> </jaxws:endpoint> </beans>

section.para: In In the example above you can see that locator client was added through configuration exactly the same way as a standard CXF feature using <jaxws:features>, and property endpointPrefix was set to locator faeture.
So in this example endpoint will register into the endpoint repository using name http://localhost:8080/locator-demo-war/GreeterService.

Property locatorEndpoints was not set. Default value will use for it. This means Locator server must started on localhost and configured for the 2181 port to listen for client connections. To learn more about installation and configuration Locator server, read Servicee Locator Installation Manual.

chapter.title: Consumer side configuration
chapter.para:

Property name
Description
locatorEndpoints
Service Locator endpoints must be configurable in the feature. If not, the default localhost endpoint "localhost:2181" is taken as long as nobody sets new endpoints via setLocatorEndpoints. The service locator client will one by one pick an endpoint (the order is non-deterministic) to connect to the service locator until a connection is established.
connectionTimeout
specify the time the service locator client waits for a connection to get established. Must be greater than zero, by default 5000 ms.

Must be greater than zero and less than 60000, by default 5000 ms.

example.title: Talend ESB ServiceLocator Feature configuration for client
example.programlisting:
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:jaxws="http://cxf.apache.org/jaxws" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.5.xsd http://cxf.apache.org/jaxws http://cxf.apache.org/schemas/jaxws.xsd">
<import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf.xml" /> <import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf-extension-soap.xml" /> <import resource="classpath:META-INF/cxf/cxf-servlet.xml" />
<jaxws:client id="GreeterClient" serviceClass="demo.common.Greeter" address="locator://"> <jaxws:features> <bean class="org.talend.esb.locator.LocatorFeature"> <property name="locatorEndpoints" value="locator_host:2181"/> </bean> </jaxws:features> </jaxws:client> </beans>

chapter.para: In the example above you can see that Locator client was added through configuration exactly the same way as a standard CXF feature using <jaxws:features>, and property locatorEndpoints was set to locator feature. Another important point is to configure jaxws client address. We must use localor protocol for client: address="locator://more_useful_information".
Alternatively you can add the feature to the CXF service consumer by using the ClientFactoryBean.
